world inherent then to our business is that we have to be trustworthy we have
to be something which people trust because if we weren't there are any number of evil things uh that we could

sell the data uh that comes off of that Network all of which would be particularly untrustworthy things to do
and we'd be very quick ends to our business and so uh we don't do those things um but inherent to our business

an early Cloud flare customer um it was uh it was quite surprising actually when

some you know an HP server stick it in a data center connect to one of many isps

massive consolidation um across the industry and so it's sort of an acronis

the email requesting a meeting we decided to illiminate all us infrastructure providers um from our
stream and uh and we were initially going to send out a press release saying

um because that would have been a really bad day um the second thing was he said you know as you might imagine um uh we
Ed a lot of anonymizing proxies as we surf the Internet uh given given sort of
you know our situation and I've really been tracking the rise of cloud flow over time because you guys put the most
annoying captas in front of a ton of the web when you're using the tour Network
and so I have a product request Could you actually make that better and I said sure I'll take that back to to our

the thing that really you know stuck with me and it it was so absurd at the time um but I I think that it's a great
way to think about what's happening um to a lot of of these infrastructure companies online the third thing was he
said have you ever thought about Cloud Flair philosophically and I said huh and he
said well you know how nation states get started and I said Mr Assange you have
really lost me and he said well you know before there were nation states individuals were on their own and the
weak would get attacked by the strong and the strong would would beat them up
or Rob from them or kill them or worse and eventually the weat gets sick of it
and they say we're going to band together and we'll provide a collective defense together and we'll have people

turns into language and turns into religion and turns into culture it turns into a welfare state to protect the you
know the weakest among it system of Taxation in order to fund the upkeep of the system taxing those people that are
that are more wealthy and I was like okay don't understand what this has to do with us he said well you know we've
always thought about that from a physical perspective but increasingly I'm starting to think about that from a
digital perspective and to that end I think of cloud Flair is the first nation state of the internet at which point I
burst out laughing because that's absurd except for that it's step still stuck with me and it still makes me think that
as the in the privileged position where we are where we have taken a whole bunch of weak organizations huddled them
together provided a collective defense you know starting with Turkish escorts and and ending with Goldman Sachs and
and others um we that we have a responsibility as that infrastructure
provider to think about what our policies are and be very transparent and very clear about those policies and more
than anything be extremely consistent and not arbitrary when we think about uh those policies and and and I think that
that's something that more and more of the organizations that sit in this trusted position really need to
appreciate and think about and and at some level again as we watch this transition happen where we're moving
from Individual weak parties collecting behind the cloud flares and the
Facebooks and the Googles and the aamis of the world it's incumbent on those users those citizens of these effective
nation states to hold them accountable for what their policies are and decide what those policies are and different
nation states of the internet are going to have different policies and so ours is not so much around free speech um but
really around due process around an idea that we should be transparent in what it
is that we're doing and we are subject we're not anarchists we're subject to us laws and our response uh when we when we

something that shows that we've gone through a democratically sanctioned process in order to decide whether this

that means that if there's an organization on our site that someone doesn't like I don't care how much

this on the other side of the coin as well and I'll give you an example of that um one of the things I think I just
lost the mic um one of the things that uh do we
have hello I'll just speak loudly um one of the things that we recognized was a
uh a a challenge was that you know we provide pretty robust Enterprise dos
mitigation service but it costs a lot um and and there are a lot of politically
or artistically important sites that uh can't necessarily afford to pay for that
that service or that content and so we said we should do something to help protect these organizations that are
doing the right thing are working in the Pol in the in the interest of either our
societal interest or artistic interests um and we should protect them even if they don't have the ability to pay and
so we launched something uh last year uh about a year ago uh called project Galileo and the idea of project Galileo
was really simple it was that if you are a politically or artistically important site and you come under attack will
protect you and we'll throw our entire resources behind keeping you who there we go behind uh keeping you online
um but what we really wanted to avoid was just in the same way we don't want
to determine who's bad and we don't think it's appropriate for us to determine who's bad we also don't want
to be the organization that's determining who's good that's not the right place for the infrastructure
provider for us to say oh yeah that's artistically important but that isn't artistic Ally important and so the
solution that we came up with I thought was actually pretty clever which is we reached out to a number of civil society
and NGO Partners uh companies or organizations that you've all sort of entrusted uh and we tried to span the
political Spectrum uh here and said before we accept someone into project
Galileo you have to vouch for them and if any one of these organizations vouches for a particular organization
that is under attack then we'll take their word for it even if we personally philosophically disagree with what is on
that site um and we've we've tried to live up to that and I think the best test of this uh actually was almost the
very first uh test of it which was we got a uh a call from from our friends
over at the eff and they said oh my gosh we have the perfect Galileo uh customer or user for you um you know it it
follows the very principle that bullies shouldn't be able to censor the internet you know we had heard about it
originally from you know the folks at occupy Toronto that said occupy Central uh needed uh some protection and and the

night uh the 19th of June in San Francisco the 20th June in in uh in Hong Kong we actually brought cots in for our

though was some of the layer 7 attacks um there there's sort of a boring HTTP flood uh there was a really interesting
https attack where they um they actually picked Cipher Suites that were
particularly computationally intensive for us to resolve and sent a whole bunch of requests to that and that was a point
where like wow there's some smart people on the other side of this um it was really easy to defeat though we just
turned the cipher Suite off um the really scary one though was the DNS floods where we were getting over 250
million valid DNS queries per second uh from spoofed IP addresses uh that were
being requests for pop vote.com and that was challenging for a couple of reasons one was there's no way to really filter
out uh of you can't tell whether it's a valid request or invalid request and so
you can't separate those out the other thing that was particularly pernicious was a lot of the Upstream DNS resolvers
saw this as an attack against their infrastructure so they shut them down Upstream from us so even if we were had
the capability to uh be able to respond to the attacks at this volume the Upstream providers would keep them
offline and there's still Upstream providers in in certain regions I was I was just in the UK and you still to this

would we be able to stay online um and and we're pretty proud of the fact that we were able to keep uh this free
